subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] I need clarification on British pronunciations.
msgSnippet: ... After vowels, that is. ... As a conscious compromise with people who do, and because the missing /r/ leaves a trace after front vowels: thus near is
messageBody:
Henry Jones my_socks_smell@... [Read_Alphabet] scripsit:

> Thank you for the information. You said that there is no pronounced
> "r" in Read's accent.

After vowels, that is.

> If that is the case, why did he consistently use letter 25 (alone and
> combined with vowels) in his manual? 

As a conscious compromise with people who do, and because the missing
/r/ leaves a trace after front vowels: thus "near" is [nɪə], not just
[ni].

> as far as my ears can tell, here "hole" and "hull", and "whole" for
> that manner are identical in their pronunciation.

In most American accents "hole" and "whole" are [hoʊl], but "hull" is
[hʌl]. However, vowels may shift slightly before /l/.

> 32 & 34 are still throwing me for a loop.

332 is [ɑː] in RP (Read's accent), a long vowel, whereas 34 is [ɒ],
a short vowel. In AmE (other than Eastern New England), they merge
as [ɑ], whose length varies depending on the context. However,
the important point is having three vowels, not exactly which three
vowels they are. In Australian English, 32 is [aː], 33 is o[oː],
and 34 is [ɔ], all quite different from RP, but maintaining the
same distinctions, unlike the North American situation where some
distinctions are lost, either between 32 and 34 (Northeast and South),
between 33 and 34 (Eastern New England), or all three (West and Canada).

> The fact that that there is no satisfactory combination for the
> butter still bugs me. Using # 25 as a vowel sounds like a good idea,
> but it doesn't work if that sound is at the beginning of the word.  

Why not? How would you read 25-23 except as "earn" (or "urn"), and
25-2-36-23 except as "urban"?

--
John Cowan http://www.ccil.org/~cowan cowan@...
It's the old, old story. Droid meets droid. Droid becomes chameleon.
Droid loses chameleon, chameleon becomes blob, droid gets blob back
again. It's a classic tale. --Kryten, Red Dwarf
